document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Science

11C1AD561E2344BB9E59B40ED47E27BB.description:
Engage with models that demonstrate objects moving at
different speeds.

8C26255ABF1A48899F474DFE4BD4E022.description: Engage with timers when observing movement of objects.

7D8DDB4E61004BF6B1E2DE8E05401359.description:
Engage with graphs representing objects moving at high
and low speeds.

D4177199D64B4A31B8B6011E9AB7008E.description:
Manipulate the heights and slopes of a ramp to change
how fast and how far an object like a ball travels.

C61A21E6A3ED4B53978D831404052BCC.description:
Recognize that on a speed graph (showing distance vs.
time)a line with represented with a steep slope is an
object moving faster than a line represented by a low
slope.

BA5763989B8A448199B87811F4862B55.description:
Identify how a model must be manipulated to change the
speed and direction of an object according to specific
requirements (e.g., increase the speed, change the
direction of motion and distance to the left).

029BD386DB66401BAAE4F675EE754340.description:
Match different ramp characteristics to graphs that
represent an object’s motion.

BBCD7CF9A7B64AEBBFF4859CDFB66C7B.description:
Identify
factors that affect
the speed of an
object.

CFC0DA0CE0454D07B49AB530A9F9EB29.description:
Identify the
speed and direction of
a moving object.

0078C9DB9CD14BC4B08E8B500146F370.description:
Explain
how speed
involves both
distance and time.

0F4D5D1D4E7C41A680A6FEDBDB87190E.description:
An object’s motion
can be described by its speed
and the direction in which
it is moving. An object’s
position can be measured and
graphed as a function of time.

DD445C8611164EE1ACEA7DB46D10E393.description: Engage with various objects that are at rest or in motion.

C976F1C1C5DC491E90F73B0F098124F4.description: Identify if an object is in motion or at rest.

6A00DE200C23466DA711295075C63232.description:
Recognize that objects in motion are said to have “kinetic”
energy and those at rest have “potential” energy.

128BB95AEBEC4DB39CBB8ECBB845DAA3.description:
Match picture examples to either having kinetic or
potential energy.

2C888263B9784818942F2077D92302F2.description:
Model the effect of an increase or decrease of potential
energy on an object’s kinetic energy (e.g., drop a ball from
different heights and compare the heights of the resulting
bounces--”If I drop a ball from really high, the bounce will
be bigger.”; skiing on the bunny hill versus advanced hill).

CE51F2E7DD26483FB37BCBC794486B17.description:
(Example for 6.PS.3c) Observe a Rube Goldberg machine
(Mouse Trap game) in action and identify the types energy
employed. Identify places where potential and kinetic
energy are the greatest or least. (think Mouse Trap game).

2E08ED64F89A4EF1B7B1F5361B168EE3.description:
Identify
examples of
potential or
kinetic energy in
a model or visual
representation.

C76C0CA134B84EC58D4BA008EEE23C10.description:
Recognize
that the potential
energy of an object
changes based on its
height and recognize
that the kinetic energy
of an object changes
based on its speed.

89F02D84ED844A0AA4F11B1056197164.description:
Identify
when an object
has the greatest/
least kinetic and/or
potential energy.

91BFEAE4F1BB4732B7AA4912AC08E573.description:
There are two
categories of energy: kinetic
and potential. Objects and
substances in motion have
kinetic energy. Objects and
substances can have energy
as a result of their position
(potential energy). Note:
Chemical and elastic potential
energy should not be included
at this grade; this is found in
PS grade 7.

24183375A05C4D41B65EC5504C8BC610.description:
Engage with various solids, liquids, and gases that can
change their state within a relatively short amount of time.

AAF72FC478714EA493F5AAC1B14A24B9.description:
Actively participate in discussion about a change in state
demonstration (e.g., ice changing state from solid to liquid
to gas on a hot plate).

52C57421D35D4C00A28B2CE9424AD250.description:
Engage with an animation of particle movement as
a substance changes phase as a result of adding or
removing heat.

A04200B5D361472C89AE59A1B829D2C1.description:
Identify the states of matter that exist as ice melts (e.g.,
solid, liquid, gas).

3932A07B82FF47DF9330830F2F30276F.description:
Recognize a “change of state” as matter changing from
liquid to solid, liquid to gas, solid to liquid, etc.)

A3EC03EA5CE64E6CA35A7E9F0404C3F1.description:
Recognize that matter is made of particles (atoms) that
move.

A344698E89814FF7BA083ED8E2232BA4.description:
Recognize that particles in matter move according to their
“state” (solid-particles vibrate, liquid-particles move around
each other, gas-particles move in all directions).

92578970D2FF403FA356A3F0BB4436BF.description: Model movement of particles in each state of matter.

29B708DC1EEC405C8637C5F82B1D6DB8.description:
Relate particle movement to the characteristics of the
various states of matter, e.g., liquids and gases flow and
take the shape of their container because atoms move
over and around each other. Solids have a definite shape
due to the limited movement of the atoms.

C0FB19F09C184138A748054C62AF577F.description:
Identify what is present to cause a change of state (i.e.
increased energy or heat).

CC5C4B17761848739A9E50E323F1EE5E.description:
Model movement of particles in a state of matter as heat
or energy is added or taken away.

67816ADC06B34F268B5381A5B1E8EE6A.description:
Recognize
that heating an
object can make
it change from a
solid to a liquid to
a gas.

6211D104129A4C009DBE9A80DBA01A3B.description:
Identify that
heating an object
causes the particles
of the object to speed
up.

91112C848A4B4BF6B3C34A1DC4CE1E79.description:
Compare
the motion of the
particles that make
up solids, liquids,
gases (e.g., solid
particles are close
together; gas
particles are far
apart).

6F602DE3F6534E8FBD03E1077F142FF8.description:
Changes of state
are explained by a model
of matter composed of
particles that are in motion.
Temperature is a measure
of the average motion of the
particles in a substance. Heat
is a process of energy transfer
rather than a type of energy.
Energy transfer can result
in a change in temperature
or a phase change. When
substances undergo changes
of state, atoms change their
motion and position. Note: It is
not the intent of this standard
to encourage vocabulary
identification (matching
definitions with heat,
temperature, and thermal
energy). Instead, these are
provided as conceptual tools
for understanding the role
of energy in physical, biotic,
atmospheric, oceanic, and
geologic systems covered
in grade 6 and subsequent
grades and courses.

8E74C8CE542F46AF85DED154ED2CD3FE.description:
Engage with items of the same size and shape, but
varying masses, or items of same mass, but varying sizes/
shapes.

5E62B769B7894DEC9DE8C26BE34B3D0F.description:
Engage with objects that represent “building blocks”
(e.gi.e., smaller pieces that can be put together to create a
larger object, such as Legos).

E46CEA1B33B94C0AAFA062659BAE6AA2.description: Engage with models of atoms and molecules.

155425CBDB3D45D78B49FF571AC7BEBA.description:
Engage with a visual representation of atoms of elements
such as the Periodic Table of Elements.

3CDF36C5686144B0A168ABA22EAAD49D.description:
Recognize the size of an atom compared to an everyday
object (i.e. understand that atoms can’t be seen with the
naked just their eyes).

88226D3DA1A7414A855D2916F0EAFB24.description:
Recognize that objects can be broken down into smaller
and smaller pieces that eventually we cannot see (e.g.,
physically reduce the size of various objects (break them
down into smaller and smaller pieces until they can no
longer be reduced)).

C2237BE5D91F465EB303584141C19D58.description:
Recognize atoms as the “building blocks” of all substances
(i.e. they make up everything).

9F5794F8AD5A46198540A6CBEA799594.description:
Recognize unique characteristics of substances (e.g.,
size, color, malleability, mass, volume).

617FD3741CCB44A39A2D689502EE1222.description:
Make a model representing atoms joined together to
create a substance (e.g., use Legos to create an object
or “substance”, then change the size, number, or color of
Legos to create a new “substance”).

14D539AFB672474F840CF7CC90DFAB0B.description:
Explore different materials of the same size and note
similarities and difference. (Use a steellead beaarring and
a foam ball of the same size and note the mass, volume
and density.)

8BB2CA6609184EE184C201011C9A7B7C.description:
Identify
that matter is made
of atoms, which
are too small to be
seen.

6C24C182FA8D4D89B2C72B43D5351BDD.description:
Identify a
property of matter
that can be measured
(e.g., mass, volume,
density).

E2C913ABAE894C449580DAA8041245A8.description:
Compare
objects based on
the properties of
matter (e.g., mass,
volume, density).

60383DF8A8B7494CA913337369ED2B57.description:
Matter is made up of
small particles called atoms.
Matter has mass, volume
and density and is made up
of particles called atoms.
Elements are a class of
substances composed of a
single kind of atom. Molecules
are the combination of two or
more atoms that are joined
together chemically.

CD02863FC70C4986A1F4859097C358A6.description:
Engage with pictures and models of various types of cells
(plant and animal).

16FB226AC90145A699BBA13DF397B550.description:
Recognize at least one difference between a plant and
animal cell (e.g., cell wall versus cell membrane, presence
or absence of chloroplasts).

326E298FC9F44938B8C8C2BF3B4DFC54.description:
Recognize that a group of similar cells make up a larger
structure called “tissue”.

8887B45DD3C64A2298A06A5E5FACE4FE.description:
Recognize that similar tissues put together make up an
organ.

58AC7FC898B74122A008BDCA3BD01B13.description:
Recognize that organs that work together to perform a
specific job make up an organ system

3986616DB8774AE0A3D9F68AAAF75A2A.description:
Recognize that all organs/organ systems work together to
provide function for an organism.

119D114B96E943EE95F867A66ACC47F2.description:
Identify a
plant cell and an
animal cell.

99BAA4C1BBC4420E8E9A1E313609E7CF.description:
Identify that
cells make up tissues,
which make up
organs.

7CF02053879C4168BC265F2CE6ACCEBE.description:
Compare
and contrast
different types of
cells and tissues.

C308D7B3388D42A7BACBD6B466C95F31.description:
Living systems at
all levels of organization
demonstrate the
complementary nature
of structure and function.
The level of organization
within organisms includes
cells, tissues, organs,
organ systems, and whole
organisms. Whether the
organism is single-celled or
multicellular, all parts function
as a whole to perform the
tasks necessary for the
survival of the organism.

A800B6EEB3154A1684BD58A739EC6424.description:
Engage with and manipulate a cell model to illustrate cell
parts (both plant and animal).

9DCBCAE2CE684715A52120BE69FAF88A.description:
Recognize that cells have smaller parts called
“organelles”.

78C8C16A12544889B0AF3F943082CD2A.description:
Identify at least one difference between a plant and animal
cell (e.g., cell wall versus cell membrane, presence or
absence of chloroplasts).

827BF912A60A43A9B367BB4F47271663.description:
Identify an
organelle in a cell.

D549E85C06EC4A3FBEB98E704F7F1C68.description:
Match
an organelle to its
function.

E13665FEADAC4AC8A898085B69A18955.description:
Explain
that each cell
part has a distinct
structure and
function that is
critical to life.

D21134AF0F9B4D1F8A1DECEE36D34DF0.description:
Cells carry on specific
functions that sustain life.
Many basic functions of
organisms occur in cells.
Cells take in nutrients and
energy to perform work, like
making various molecules
required by that cell or an
organism. Every cell is
covered by a membrane that
controls what can enter and
leave the cell. Within the cell
are specialized parts for the
transport of materials, energy
capture and release, protein
building, waste disposal,
information feedback, and
movement. Note: Emphasis
should be placed on the
function and coordination of
cell components, as well as
on their roles in overall cell
function.

06A69D5CE2BC4653B7BE919320E9ED4E.description:
Engage with or manipulate a model of a cell (both plant and
animal).

D3FA259C9EFD41CCAB34B35F93CF1BE7.description:
Engage with models or visuals of single-celled and multicellular
organisms (both plant and animal).

003E58075D404CC8B51E25AC94E056F7.description:
Identify relative size of a single cell to a known organism or
object (e.g., have students engage with various models to
describe the relative size of a cell).

D116D06394AC4405866E3C866FAD8E3F.description: Identify a single-celled versus a multicellular organism.

CBC063757976420B8AB5E143D0A4B460.description:
Compare differences between plants and animals at the macro
and microscopic level.

309CD33C935B409FBA7B7966BA73E627.description:
Identify that a cell has smaller parts that perform their own
functions for living things.

A769CAF254AF4890960ED21329E1F0F5.description:
Identify the needs of all living things (energy, removal of waste,
reproduction, etc.).

817C266045C74E47AC450DB64A5D8E90.description:
Recognize that cells work together to perform different functions
for the organism (e.g., groups of special cells work together to
create an organ called the heart that pumps blood throughout an
organism’s body).

198F575A6BDD43AC9B0012C8B273979D.description:
Engage in visual models or animations of a cell dividing and
creating an exact copy.Match cell organelles to the specific
function they perform in a cell.

64C97301E85A46AABE987C4FE28C0DCD.description:
Engage in visual models or animations of a cell dividing and
developing into an embryo.

190787D1E0814F3992C54C6643A24590.description:
Actively participate in discussion of how organisms grow or how
bodies make repairs (e.g., what happens when you get a cut?)

1127E77DF1A7476282F8EAF1DDFEE5E7.description:
Identify the source of a specific type of cell (e.g., muscle cell was
produced from another muscle cell).

E8DD59AE348048D9BA710137FE530537.description:
Recognize that cell division results in growth of an organism or
the production of cells to replace cells.

7B3D9CD47508424B918509DA751741DB.description:
Identify a situation where a cell is multiplying in order to grow
or repair (e.g., provide images of cut on human skin and a scab
forming, cut hair and regrowth).

469484919C66470199DD89C31D03A724.description:
Recognize that cells have a master set of directions for structure
and function within a living system. For multicellular organisms,
only a portion of the genetic information is used.

1AC92AF73C854FBB8EA55EE8DADBE9F0.description:
Identify
that cells can
multiply to produce
more cells.

552EC285223141A5B4FB1B888A180702.description:
Identify that
cells multiply for
growth, repair, and
reproduction.

D933993985944ABBBA813BF3C41D5C2B.description:
Describe
that every
cell contains
information about
traits that can be
passed to the next
generation through
reproduction or cell
division.

B1D601FD15F241D39E7465A5C5AF3DE4.description:
All cells come from
pre-existing cells. Cells
repeatedly divide, resulting
in more cells and growth
and repair in multicellular
organisms. Note: This is
not a detailed discussion
of the phases of mitosis or
meiosis. The focus should
be on reproduction as
a means of transmitting
genetic information from one
generation to the next, cellular
growth, and repair.

B99FF6E0348B416BB7BF3703C23CE966.description:
Engage with or manipulate a model of a cell (both plant
and animal).

6733D2C081624107B834FEC6D1C06B38.description:
Engage with models or visuals of single-celled and
multicellular organisms (both plant and animal).

0B564CB0D3804215901893BBAF1B0398.description:
Identify relative size of a single cell to a known organism
or object (e.g., have students engage with various models
to describe the relative size of a cell).

3DD7402FCD3840699797AB544FBACAB4.description: Identify a single-celled versus a multicellular organism.

D707341850CC4A1FA8C28349505E5381.description:
Compare differences between plants and animals at the
macro- and microscopic level.

C1888503BA5846C893FE1F3731E18BEE.description:
Identify that a cell has smaller parts that perform their own
functions for living things.

89E77D3E8A254580871CC8E1DD3699A9.description:
Identify the needs of all living things (energy, removal of
waste, reproduction, etc.).

FAEC4F6FF90C4834A1948D52500CA5EA.description:
Recognize that cells work together to perform different
functions for the organism (e.g., groups of special cells
work together to create an organ called the heart that
pumps blood throughout an organism’s body).

1F1FBF8ECEB24A5E988434508D1F5D72.description:
Match cell organelles to the specific function they perform
in a cell.

B5D54EE1FAF04C0B881E16A529736A42.description:
Recognize
that living things
are made of cells.

C1B9610C5780483183AC296AEC0FF792.description:
Recognize
that organisms can
be made of only one
cell or can be made of
many cells.

1743B220CB5C4D8A8A1E9245A0291242.description:
Explain
how cells are
organized to
form multicellular
organisms (cells
make up tissue
such as muscle).

4DF16E28CF924AB1A6E1620C6201FBFF.description:
Cells are the
fundamental unit of life. All
living things are composed
of cells. Different body
tissues and organs are made
of different kinds of cells.
The ways cells function are
similar in all living organisms.
Note: Emphasis should
be placed on the function
and coordination of cell
organelles as well as their
roles in overall cell function.
Specific information about the
organelles that need to be
addressed at this grade level
will be found in the model
curriculum.

C66BFE26D20C45479EAF569E28F3A0B2.description:
Engage with common products that are made with rocks,
minerals, or soils.

BDF59FBA6D1F41B1A71754C2CB6E48F4.description:
Identify the practical use of rocks, minerals, or soils found
in everyday items.

998D2C48FEB747C5BB696C77F736F8DC.description:
Match a rock or mineral to its industrial use (e.g., road salt,
jewellery, building material, etc.).

105A1DA359354A76B72686C953B628D8.description:
Identify what happens when a nonrenewable resource is
used (e.g., coal is burned up to create heat).

3B54CFF98AF4481DBC820CA6AB364F2E.description:
Identify
that rocks,
minerals, and soils
are nonrenewable
resources that are
used by people in
many ways.

9E2D7F5B5CFF4102813F7E486B6E5683.description:
Identify
a common use for
rocks, minerals, or
soils.

70D0ADFE8B3F4F72B2EB858EE1FB2857.description:
Classify
specific rocks,
minerals, or soils
into their general
use (agriculture,
transportation,
construction,
domestic, energy,
and technology).

4B03F7C5FD5D46E2AE3A3C08F4CA2101.description:
Rocks, minerals,
and soils have common
and practical uses. Nearly
all manufactured material
requires some kind of
geologic resource. Most
geologic resources are
considered nonrenewable.
Rocks, minerals, and
soil are examples of
geologic resources that are
nonrenewable.

F49CE11BE0D849CCAB35B0D26296DEA6.description: Engage with different samples of soil.

D4E0D372CF88420D81B7D335A35D7060.description:
Manipulate different soil samples to identify characteristics
of each (e.g., texture, color, composition, permeability,
porosity).

E36191418F6C4784BCA9C065B6A0246A.description:
Identify the different layers in a soil sample/cross section
as “horizons”.

13FDD33D44694F3F8DBC678A9F258343.description: Match characteristics of soil to its purpose or use.

CA59EF7A7D5D4B50A00CE92F61C8F6AB.description: Investigate plant growth in a variety of soils.

3CEFF8F90D194EEE94385C5053EF9961.description:
Identify
the components
of soil (e.g., small
pieces of rock and
living and decaying
organisms).

AC73AF4BFA0649AE992CDDBBA9B507A3.description:
Recognize
that soils can have
different properties
(e.g., texture,
color, composition,
permeability,
porosity).

AE8A2CDB765046C2B35A97E83FBBD0BA.description:
Identify
the different
properties of each
layer (horizon) of
soil.

6BD6417605CF4BFAB21EBD69B40CAB7F.description:
Soil is
unconsolidated material that
contains nutrient matter and
weathered rock. Soil formation
occurs at different rates and
is based on environmental
conditions, types of existing
bedrock, and rates of
weathering. Soil forms in
layers known as horizons. Soil
horizons can be distinguished
from one another based
on properties that can be
measured. The terms dirt
and soil are not synonymous;
use the term “soil.” Note:
The emphasis should be on
properties of soil rather than
memorization.

EB572DD05AD34451896D667ABECB5BCA.description:
Engage with materials that can represent the formation of
rocks (e.g., different colors of playdoh).

CBC29D151C224E9E92351D513D3F83CD.description:
Engage with various visual or tactile representations of the
rock cycle.

7D2BBEF5844E4E008B116813E99234A0.description:
Actively participate in discussion about an animation or
simulation that illustrates the rock cycle (e.g., the creation
of coal).

E068E0624DCD4CAD94029DE4AF665458.description:
Identify the processes that can change a rock (e.g., heat,
pressure, lava cooling, etc.).

6B0E6178DC77445C918EBC5E3EDF469F.description:
Explore a variety of different rocks and identify specific
characteristics of the rock.

4243B80DAF7848D9BFE9D8FC5E255377.description: Match where a given rock fits into the rock cycle.

E2DF8FF3CF814709B7F7C5A5BCFDC476.description:
Given characteristics of a rock or location in the rock
cycle, identify the specific rock type.

910ED379E37345F284DEC87996F965C2.description:
Identify
a component of a
rock cycle.

054B2D11B3DB403B99A838B2493D2896.description:
Compare
parts of the rock cycle
(e.g., some rocks
form from pressure
while some form from
lava).

8E3324037FE34C52BB6721F659C87C5E.description:
Identify how
each rock type
is formed (e.g.,
pressure, erosion,
cooling, melting,
compaction,
cementation,
heat, and/or
weathering).

9E509E31B6884C6F9E7BD2A29CE94122.description:
Igneous,
metamorphic, and
sedimentary rocks form in
different ways. Magma or
lava cools and crystallizes to
form igneous rocks. Heat and
pressure applied to existing
rock forms metamorphic
rocks. Sedimentary rock forms
as existing rock weathers
chemically and/or physically
and the weathered material
is compressed and then
lithifies. Each rock type can
provide information about the
environment in which it was
formed.

DD006CBEEB024074949856B391A2F6B2.description: Engage with various types of rocks.

B929D19DB16345509AF5273A62C84C6A.description:
Manipulate rocks to identify textural characteristics of
each.

2A5AA3653A09417E8065D2B682F53493.description:
Match a sample rock to its origin given a set of
characteristics (e.g., using pictures, maps, illustrations,
etc.)

54ED44D0067C4E8FB5258F4DC793F7DB.description:
Compare the characteristics of igneous, metamorphic and
sedimentary rocks.

09D2A07B512942C99150B75A540FF0F0.description:
Identify the
properties of igneous
rocks (e.g., granite,
basalt), metamorphic
rocks (e.g., marble,
quartzite), or
sedimentary rocks
(layers).

F122D40F46C740DAB3F7E9C0ADEC3D2A.description:
Classify igneous,
metamorphic, or
sedimentary rocks.

DBBB1A3DB41C47F4A323F9FBF797BD74.description:
Igneous,
metamorphic, and
sedimentary rocks have
unique characteristics that
can be used for identification
and/or classification. Most
rocks are composed of one or
more minerals, but there are
a few types of sedimentary
rocks that contain organic
material, such as coal. The
composition of the rock, types
of mineral present, and/or
mineral shape and size can
be used to identify the rock
and to interpret its history
of formation, breakdown
(weathering), and transport
(erosion).

81C56046AD054829868326189C1C2D5D.description: Engage with various minerals and rocks.

37CC46FF237F4A64A73AEA4BEEF896C2.description:
Manipulate both rocks and minerals to identify
characteristics of each (e.g., rubbing on a piece of paper,
breaking into pieces, feeling texture, etc.)

30B5F1493D4245AC8FF87477C502D259.description:
Match a sample rock or mineral to a given set of
properties.

383F2666D0B043918FAA944F76E0E8EF.description:
Identify
an object as a
mineral or a rock.

108FF3FF5159459ABA80C277331B1AC0.description:
Sort
minerals by
properties (e.g.,
color, density,
luster).

2845B0F5C396400BBBD4A335C64F479B.description:
Minerals have
specific, quantifiable
properties. Minerals are
naturally occurring, inorganic
solids that have a defined
chemical composition.
Minerals have properties
that can be observed and
measured. Minerals form in
specific environments.
